lessons.title: Lesson 1 — Bending knees, squaring up
lessons.question: What's the first step to setting up a balanced basketball shot?
options: Stand tall with knees locked
Bend your knees and square your shoulders to the hoop
Keep feet together and lean forward
Hold the ball above your head right away

lessons.title: Lesson 2 — Shooting arm at right angle
lessons.question: Where should your shooting elbow be positioned before you release the ball?
options: Out to the side
Below your waist
Right under the ball at a ninety-degree angle
Behind your back

lessons.title: Lesson 3 — Hand placement (shooting hand under, guide hand on side)
lessons.question: How should you hold the ball before starting your shooting motion?
options: Shooting hand on top, guide hand under
Both hands gripping from the sides
Shooting hand under the ball, guide hand on the side
Cradle the ball against your stomach

lessons.title: Lesson 4 — Follow-through (wrist snap, fingers down)
lessons.question: What does a good follow-through look like after you shoot?
options: Arms stiff by your sides
Wrists snapped and fingers pointed toward the rim
Hands waving in the air
Shoulders leaning backward

lessons.title: Lesson 5 — Full shot, power from legs
lessons.question: Where does most of the power for your shot come from?
options: Your arms only
Your shoulders and back
Your legs and whole body working together
Just your fingertips

final_quiz.q: Why is bending your knees important when you're getting ready to shoot?
options: It gives you better jumping height
It helps you stay balanced and control your shot
It makes it easier to run fast
It keeps your arms loose for passing

final_quiz.q: If your shooting elbow is too far out to the side, what will most likely happen?
options: You'll shoot a straighter shot
The ball will go left or right instead of straight
You'll have more power in your shot
It will help you jump higher

final_quiz.q: What is the main job of your guide hand when you hold the ball?
options: Add extra power to the shot
Spin the ball while shooting
Keep the ball steady without pushing it
Push the ball forward with your fingers

final_quiz.q: What does holding your follow-through after shooting help with?
options: It improves your balance and shooting accuracy
It helps you run back faster on defense
It gives more backspin on the ball
It makes you jump higher

final_quiz.q: When taking a jump shot, where should most of your shooting power come from?
options: Your legs pushing upward through your whole body
Your wrists snapping really hard
Your shoulders and arms swinging forward
Your fingertips flicking the ball as fast as possible
